terms.shortDefinition: HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management looks back to a long tradition, deeply rooted in the region of Saxony while at the same time enjoying a highly international reputation. HHL is known for its mixture of innovative, international and individual approaches by students, staff, faculty and alumni.
terms.definition: HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management is a prestigious university with doctoral and habilitation rights and was the first private German Business School with AACSB accreditation. In addition, with more than 530 startups founded by HHL Alumni, our business school is the top address for entrepreneurship in Germany.

terms.shortDefinition: (Large Language Model) AI models trained on vast text data to understand and generate human-like text
terms.definition: Large Language Models are neural networks with billions of parameters trained on massive text datasets. They can understand context, generate coherent text, answer questions, and perform various language tasks. Examples include GPT-4, Claude, and PaLM.

terms.shortDefinition: Algorithms that learn patterns from data without explicit programming
terms.definition: Machine Learning is a subset of AI where systems automatically learn and improve from experience. Instead of being explicitly programmed, ML algorithms identify patterns in data to make predictions or decisions.

terms.shortDefinition: AI field focused on enabling computers to understand and process human language
terms.definition: Natural Language Processing combines linguistics and machine learning to help computers understand, interpret, and generate human language. Applications include translation, sentiment analysis, text summarization, and chatbots.

terms.shortDefinition: Neural network architecture using attention mechanisms, foundational to modern LLMs
terms.definition: Transformers are a neural network architecture introduced in 2017 that revolutionized NLP. They use self-attention mechanisms to process sequential data in parallel, making them highly efficient and effective. They're the foundation of models like GPT, BERT, and modern LLMs.

terms.shortDefinition: Using neural networks to automatically translate text between languages
terms.definition: Neural Machine Translation uses deep learning models to translate text from one language to another. Modern NMT systems use transformer architectures and can produce more fluent, context-aware translations than older statistical methods.

terms.shortDefinition: Translation method using an intermediate language as a bridge
terms.definition: The pivot technique in machine translation uses a high-resource language (like English) as an intermediate bridge when translating between two low-resource languages. For example, translating Swahili→Finnish via Swahili→English→Finnish.

terms.shortDefinition: Ensemble learning method using multiple decision trees
terms.definition: Random Forests are a machine learning algorithm that creates multiple decision trees and merges their predictions. This ensemble approach reduces overfitting and improves accuracy compared to single decision trees.

terms.shortDefinition: Statistical method for classification and dimensionality reduction
terms.definition: Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) is a technique used to find linear combinations of features that best separate different classes. It's used both for classification and reducing data dimensions while preserving class separability.

terms.shortDefinition: Architectural pattern where applications are built as independent, loosely-coupled services
terms.definition: Microservices architecture structures an application as a collection of small, independent services that communicate via APIs. Each service runs its own process, can be deployed independently, and focuses on a specific business capability.

terms.shortDefinition: Platform for developing and running applications in isolated containers
terms.definition: Docker is a containerization platform that packages applications and their dependencies into standardized units called containers. Containers are lightweight, portable, and ensure consistent behavior across different environments.

terms.shortDefinition: Packaging software with all dependencies into isolated, portable units
terms.definition: Containerization bundles an application's code, runtime, libraries, and configuration into a single package that can run consistently across different computing environments. Unlike VMs, containers share the host OS kernel, making them lightweight and fast.

terms.shortDefinition: Minimal container images containing only the application and runtime dependencies
terms.definition: Distroless images are Docker images stripped of everything except the application and its runtime dependencies—no shell, package managers, or unnecessary tools. This reduces attack surface, image size, and improves security.

terms.shortDefinition: Docker technique using multiple FROM statements to optimize image size
terms.definition: Multistage builds use multiple FROM statements in a Dockerfile, allowing you to copy artifacts from one stage to another. This keeps final images small by excluding build tools and intermediate files.

terms.shortDefinition: Infrastructure layer for managing service-to-service communication in microservices
terms.definition: A service mesh is a dedicated infrastructure layer that handles communication between microservices. It provides features like load balancing, service discovery, encryption, authentication, and observability without changing application code.

terms.shortDefinition: Culture and practices combining software development and IT operations
terms.definition: DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten development cycles and deliver high-quality software continuously. It emphasizes automation, collaboration, and rapid feedback.

terms.shortDefinition: (Developer Experience) Tools, processes, and environments that affect developer productivity and satisfaction
terms.definition: Developer Experience encompasses everything that affects how developers interact with their tools and workflows. Good DevEx means fast feedback loops, minimal friction, clear documentation, and productive development environments.

terms.shortDefinition: Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment/Delivery pipelines
terms.definition: CI/CD automates building, testing, and deploying code. Continuous Integration merges code changes frequently and runs automated tests. Continuous Deployment/Delivery automatically deploys tested code to production or staging.

terms.shortDefinition: Automated code analysis to detect errors, bugs, and style violations
terms.definition: Linting uses static analysis tools to scan code for potential errors, bugs, stylistic issues, and suspicious patterns. Linters enforce code quality standards and catch problems before runtime.

terms.shortDefinition: Scripts that run automatically before each git commit
terms.definition: Pre-commit hooks are scripts that execute before a commit is finalized. They can run tests, format code, check for sensitive data, or enforce coding standards, preventing bad code from entering the repository.

terms.shortDefinition: Protocols for secure, encrypted communication over networks
terms.definition: SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and its successor TLS (Transport Layer Security) are cryptographic protocols that provide secure communication over networks. They encrypt data in transit and verify server authenticity via certificates.

terms.shortDefinition: System that translates domain names to IP addresses
terms.definition: DNS is like the internet's phone book—it translates human-readable domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses (like 142.250.185.46) that computers use to identify each other on networks.

terms.shortDefinition: High-performance web server, reverse proxy, and load balancer
terms.definition: nginx is a web server known for high performance, stability, and low resource consumption. It's commonly used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, HTTP cache, and for serving static content.

terms.shortDefinition: High-performance RPC framework using Protocol Buffers
terms.definition: gRPC is a modern, high-performance Remote Procedure Call (RPC) framework developed by Google. It uses HTTP/2 for transport and Protocol Buffers for serialization, making it efficient for microservices communication.

terms.shortDefinition: React framework with server-side rendering and static site generation
terms.definition: Next.js is a React framework that enables server-side rendering, static site generation, API routes, and optimized performance out of the box. It simplifies building production-ready React applications.

terms.shortDefinition: JavaScript library for building user interfaces with reusable components
terms.definition: React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces. It uses a component-based architecture and a virtual DOM to efficiently update and render UI elements.

terms.shortDefinition: Vector database for similarity search and AI applications
terms.definition: Qdrant is a vector database optimized for storing and searching high-dimensional vectors. It's commonly used for semantic search, recommendation systems, and LLM applications like RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation).

terms.shortDefinition: NoSQL document database storing data in JSON-like format
terms.definition: MongoDB is a popular NoSQL database that stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents. It's schema-less, horizontally scalable, and well-suited for applications with evolving data structures.

terms.shortDefinition: Open-source relational database, MySQL-compatible fork
terms.definition: MariaDB is a community-driven fork of MySQL, created by MySQL's original developers. It's fully compatible with MySQL while offering additional features, better performance, and open-source governance.

terms.shortDefinition: Advanced open-source relational database with strong standards compliance
terms.definition: PostgreSQL is a powerful, open-source relational database known for its robustness, extensibility, and SQL compliance. It supports advanced features like JSONB, full-text search, and complex queries.

terms.shortDefinition: Non-relational databases optimized for specific data models and scale
terms.definition: NoSQL databases are non-relational databases designed for specific data models like documents, key-value pairs, graphs, or wide-columns. They're optimized for horizontal scaling and flexible schemas.

terms.shortDefinition: Structured Query Language for managing relational databases
terms.definition: SQL is the standard language for managing and querying relational databases. It provides commands for creating tables, inserting data, running queries, and managing database structures.

terms.shortDefinition: Distributed version control system for tracking code changes
terms.definition: Git is a distributed version control system that tracks changes in source code during development. It enables collaboration, branching, merging, and maintains a complete history of project changes.

terms.shortDefinition: EU regulation on data protection and privacy
terms.definition: The General Data Protection Regulation is a comprehensive EU law protecting personal data and privacy. It grants individuals rights over their data and imposes strict obligations on organizations processing EU citizens' data.

terms.shortDefinition: Approach embedding privacy into system design from the start
terms.definition: Privacy by Design is a framework that embeds privacy and data protection into the design and architecture of systems and processes from the beginning, rather than as an afterthought. It's a core principle of GDPR.

terms.shortDefinition: German startup grant program funding research-based business ideas
terms.definition: exist (Existenzgründungen aus der Wissenschaft) is a German federal program supporting university-based startups. Funded by the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK), it provides financial support and mentoring for founders developing innovative, research-based business ideas.

terms.shortDefinition: Strategic management template for developing business models
terms.definition: The Business Model Canvas is a one-page visual template with nine building blocks (customer segments, value propositions, channels, etc.) that helps entrepreneurs and teams design, describe, and pivot business models.

terms.shortDefinition: Methodology for building businesses through validated learning and rapid iteration
terms.definition: Lean Startup is an approach to building businesses and products that emphasizes rapid experimentation, validated learning, and iterative product releases to shorten development cycles and discover what customers actually want.

terms.shortDefinition: Developmental disorder affecting communication and behavior
terms.definition: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a developmental condition characterized by challenges with social communication and interaction, along with restricted or repetitive behaviors and interests. The 'spectrum' reflects the wide variation in challenges and strengths.

terms.shortDefinition: Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule—standardized assessment tool
terms.definition: The Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule is a semi-structured assessment used by clinicians to observe and evaluate social interaction, communication, play, and behaviors associated with autism spectrum disorder.

terms.shortDefinition: Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised—structured parent interview
terms.definition: The Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised is a structured interview conducted with parents or caregivers to gather detailed developmental history and current behaviors related to autism spectrum disorder diagnosis.

terms.shortDefinition: R framework for building interactive web applications
terms.definition: Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web applications directly from R code. It's commonly used for data visualization, dashboards, and making statistical analyses accessible without web development expertise.

terms.shortDefinition: Open-source Unix-like operating system kernel
terms.definition: Linux is a family of open-source Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel. It powers everything from servers and supercomputers to smartphones (Android) and IoT devices.

terms.shortDefinition: Document preparation system for high-quality typesetting
terms.definition: LaTeX is a document preparation system widely used in academia for scientific papers, theses, and technical documents. It excels at typesetting complex mathematical formulas, bibliographies, and professional layouts.

terms.shortDefinition: Statistical software package for data analysis
terms.definition: SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) is a software suite used for statistical analysis, data management, and data documentation. It's widely used in social sciences, health research, and market research.

terms.shortDefinition: Typed superset of JavaScript adding static type checking
terms.definition: TypeScript is a strongly-typed programming language that builds on JavaScript by adding optional static types. It catches errors during development and improves code quality and maintainability.

terms.shortDefinition: Splitting text into meaningful segments based on content understanding
terms.definition: Semantic text chunking divides documents into meaningful segments based on content and context rather than arbitrary character limits. This improves retrieval quality in RAG systems and search applications by preserving semantic coherence.

terms.shortDefinition: NLP technique for detecting emotional tone in text
terms.definition: Sentiment analysis uses NLP to identify and extract subjective information from text—determining whether content is positive, negative, or neutral. It's used for social media monitoring, customer feedback analysis, and brand reputation management.

terms.shortDefinition: Grouping documents by similar themes using ML algorithms
terms.definition: Topic clustering uses machine learning to automatically group documents or text segments by similar themes or topics. Algorithms like LDA or clustering on embeddings identify patterns and organize content without manual labeling.

terms.shortDefinition: Observable characteristics or traits of an individual
terms.definition: A phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism, resulting from the interaction of its genetic makeup with the environment. In behavioral and medical research, phenotype refers to measurable behaviors, symptoms, or physical features that define a condition or disorder.

terms.shortDefinition: Process of distinguishing between conditions with similar symptoms
terms.definition: Differential diagnosis is the systematic process clinicians use to identify a condition by distinguishing it from other disorders with similar presentations. It involves comparing symptoms, test results, and patient history to rule out alternative explanations and arrive at the correct diagnosis.

terms.shortDefinition: Statistical measures of diagnostic test accuracy
terms.definition: Sensitivity measures the proportion of actual positives correctly identified (true positive rate), while specificity measures the proportion of actual negatives correctly identified (true negative rate). In diagnostic testing, high sensitivity means few false negatives, and high specificity means few false positives.

terms.shortDefinition: Developmental condition affecting cognitive functioning and adaptive behavior
terms.definition: Intellectual disability is a developmental condition characterized by significant limitations in both intellectual functioning (reasoning, learning, problem-solving) and adaptive behavior (practical and social skills). It originates before age 18 and affects daily functioning.

terms.shortDefinition: Python NLP library for tokenization, tagging, and pipelines
terms.definition: spaCy is an open-source Python library for natural language processing that provides tokenization, tagging, parsing, and production-ready pipelines for text analysis.

terms.shortDefinition: Python testing framework for unit and integration tests
terms.definition: pytest is a Python testing framework that provides simple test discovery, powerful assertions, and fixtures for reusable test setup and teardown.

terms.shortDefinition: Python web framework for building APIs
terms.definition: FastAPI is a Python web framework for building REST APIs using type hints, offering high performance, automatic validation, and interactive documentation.

terms.shortDefinition: Schema-based binary serialization format
terms.definition: Protocol Buffers is a language-agnostic interface definition and binary serialization format used to define data schemas and exchange structured data efficiently.

terms.shortDefinition: Retrieval-augmented generation for LLM pipelines
terms.definition: Retrieval-augmented generation combines search over external sources with a language model to ground responses in retrieved context and reduce hallucinations.

terms.shortDefinition: Hosting platform for Git repositories
terms.definition: GitHub is a platform for hosting Git repositories with collaboration features like issues, pull requests, code review, and CI workflows.

terms.shortDefinition: Hosted registry for Docker images
terms.definition: Docker Hub is a hosted registry where container images can be stored, shared, and distributed.

terms.shortDefinition: Distributed version control system
terms.definition: Git is a distributed version control system for tracking changes in code, managing branches, and collaborating across teams.

terms.shortDefinition: Mathematics of symbols and equations
terms.definition: Algebra is a branch of mathematics that uses symbols and rules to solve equations and model relationships between quantities.

terms.shortDefinition: Machine control language for CNC and 3D printing
terms.definition: G-code is a numerical control language that describes toolpaths and printer instructions for CNC machines and 3D printers.

terms.shortDefinition: 3D model file format used in printing
terms.definition: STL (stereolithography) is a file format that represents 3D geometry with triangulated surfaces, commonly used for 3D printing.

terms.shortDefinition: Lightweight markup for formatting text
terms.definition: Markdown is a lightweight markup language used to format text with simple syntax for headings, lists, links, and code blocks.

terms.shortDefinition: Tree-based models for classification and regression
terms.definition: Decision Trees split data into branches based on feature rules, creating an interpretable model for classification or regression tasks.

terms.shortDefinition: Deep learning framework for model training
terms.definition: PyTorch is a deep learning framework with dynamic computation graphs, commonly used for training and deploying neural networks.

terms.shortDefinition: Neural networks for image and spatial data
terms.definition: Convolutional Neural Networks use convolution layers to learn spatial features, making them well suited for image and signal processing tasks.
